chain translation so it's obviously evolved and gone through a few phases so
the main phases that you think of is we first got started with something

uh you have a bunch of rules generated by expert linguists who understand the two
languages or multiple languages they generate a whole bunch of rules in terms of syntax
gender plural singular etc and then but this is not really scalable but
that's what was used from 1950s to 1980s
then a bunch more examples came up and then people tried out something called example-based machine translation
it was only in the 1990s for about 15 years that people actually based on these examples
tried to use some sort of statistical machine translation so things like um you know word-based

translate from one language to the other the number of words in the source text
as well as a target text do not have a one-to-one mapping sometimes even the order of the words
flip and you know that's where that's what makes this entire machine translation so much more

trying to compute the joint property of probability of word for occurring given that words one two and three has
occurred so think about something like i am attending ndc today so maybe
you have type i am attending and then it has to try and predict the next few words so the model is built
to compute such probability of a sequence of words or conditional property
so some of these applications we've actually seen screenshots of it so one is machine translation so

network was applied to problems whose input as well as target was sense
it can could be sensibly encoded with vectors of fixed dimensionality so the moment you see fixed dimensionality you

number of words when you translate from one language to the other is not necessarily a one-to-one map and
the order flips etcetera so sequences in general pose a challenge for deep neural networks just because
they require the dimensionality of the input and output to be known and fixed ahead of time and that's not always possible so if you
want to read a little bit about sequence to sequence learning there's an archive paper that is worth investing in
okay so this is the encoder decoder architecture so essentially you have
input text and then you your goal is to get the translated text
so the encoder essentially reads this input sequence one time step at a time to obtain a
large fixed dimensional vector so that's that little box in red with a bunch of numbers then essentially
what the decoder does is it extracts the output sequence from this encoded this context vector
the vector in the metal so essentially you have a variable length input sequence and you have a fixed
length context vector and then a variable length output sequence now the characters of an encoder decoder
architectures it can capture linguistic these rules and phrases etc
it obviously did improve translation performance which is good and it allows for continuous space
representation to learn phrases that preserve both semantic and synthetic structure phrases
then obviously a simple encoder decoder structure does have some limitations so this is then a sequence of sequence and
long sentences typically something more than 30 words they tend to have poor results due to that fixed
dimensionality for the decoder so that's where people came up with something called an
attention mechanism we'll get into what attention mechanism is in the next slide then the next part is also
that you know with long sentences which part of the source text do i need to focus on for translation how much attention needs to
be paid to different parts of the sentence so that's where you think of some sort
of weighted average and building a context vector so that's so we know the problem with a
simple encoded decoder and they came up with this encoder decoder with attention to solve that problem
so we know pure encoded order structure only utilizes the last output
which is not optimal for our scenario it compresses all the necessary information of the
source sentence to a fixed length vector and that makes it very difficult for neural networks to handle long sentences
so the general idea with the tension is to extend this encoder decoder architecture
by allowing the model to automatically kind of soft search parts of the source sentence that are
relevant to predicting the target word so in the next slide there is a very nice visualization which kind of
